conversation.text: Hi, today we're going to learn how to deep fry clams. I hope you're excited!
Oh wow, this i
I'm glad you're interested! Are you ready to begin?
For sure! Sorry I hit enter too quickly in my last reply! So, what's the first step? I have all the ingredients in front of me!
No problem, and that's great! First we're going to open the clams. Use a knife to pry open the shell and get to the meat to remove it
evidence: Insert a dull knife in between the shell. Saw around the shell until you cut through the hinge and open the shell.
Slide the knife in between the clam meat and the top and bottom shell to remove the meat.

conversation.text: Ok, I've just done that. Now I have to soak the clams, right?
Yes. I hope you used a dull knife for the last step, sharp blades are dangerous
I did, I did! Safety is important!
Good. Now I'm going to teach you a shortcut
Oh, I do love a good shortcut. Good food is nice, good food made quickly is even better!
So we're cutting the soaking time from 2-4 hours to about half an hour. It's not quite as good, but means a lot less time
evidence: If you are short on time, you can reduce the amount of soaking time to 20 or 30 minutes.

conversation.text: I think that's fair
Cool. So mix the water, salt and milk together. Make sure they're mixed well. Then add the clams and put it all in the fridge for half an hour
evidence: Mix the milk, water, and salt in a large bowl until well blended.
you can reduce the amount of soaking time to 20 or 30 minutes.
Place the clams in this mixture

conversation.text: Great, that's done and I've waited my time. I think this is going really well!
How do they look? Have your clams soaked up the mixture? They'll have changed colour slightly, maybe even look a little thicker
evidence: they should take in some of the moisture and flavor from the milk, water, and salt

conversation.text: They have indeed. Not safe to eat yet though, I do know there's a frying step to come
Yes, but not yet. I hope you've mixed the flour and onion. Mix them together quickly if you haven't. They'll form the batter to fry in
evidence: Stir together the all-purpose flour, corn flour, and onion powder in a shallow dish until thoroughly blended. Do this near the end of the soaking time, immediately before you prepare to take the clams out of the refrigerator.

conversation.text: I did, it's ready.
Good. You must drain the clams of the milk mixture and then cover them in the batter mix. Cover them completely, really pack it on
evidence: toss each clam into the flour mixture and dredge until all sides are coated.

conversation.text: Ok, that's not too hard. A little messy though
It can be. Is it fully on?
Yes, I used my fingers to press it on. Fully covered up
Good. Do you have a deep saucepan ready?
evidence: a heavy saucepan with deep sides

conversation.text: I do. You cannot deep fry without something actually deep enough to submerge food in
That's true. Ok, heat oil in that pan to 185 degrees celsius. On medium, it'll take a little time. Use a thermometer to monitor the temp
evidence: Bring the oil up to roughly 365 degrees Fahrenheit

conversation.text: Ok, safety first here. The oil is very hot
It is! Please be careful to not be burned by splashes. Are you wearing an apron? If not, put one on now
I am. And long sleeves too
Great. Ok, the next step is the all important one. Actually frying! Put a few clams at a time in. They'll turn brown after 3 minutes. Then use a spoon to fish them out
evidence: a few clams into the hot oil until they turn golden-brown. This should take roughly 3 minutes
Only fry a few clams at a time.
Remove fried clams from the hot oil using a heat-resistant slotted spoon

conversation.text: Yummy, these look done
Not quite yet, you need to clean off the excess oil and season them. Which kind of sauce do you like?
evidence: Drain the clams on several layers of clean paper towels and serve as desired.

conversation.text: Not many really. I prefer just to salt my food
Oh, that's interesting. Well the fried clams go great with salt and pepper. I like to eat mine with wedges and tarter sauce
evidence: You can serve the clams with salt and pepper, lemon wedges, or tartar sauce

conversation.text: Hmm... I'll remember that when serving to others
Great! Well everything should be done now. Your golden brown deep fried clams should taste delicious. Is everything good?
Yes, they really are good. Thanks for all your help
I'm glad everything went well. I'll talk to you again soon. Goodbye!
For sure! Maybe I'll bring you some clams next time. Bye!
Congratulations! You have successfully completed this cooking task.
Thank you once again

procedure.summary: Let the clams soak in the milk, water, and salt.
procedure.description: Mix the milk, water, and salt in a large bowl until well blended. Place the clams in this mixture and refrigerate for 2 to 4 hours. As the clams soak, they should take in some of the moisture and flavor from the milk, water, and salt. If you are short on time, you can reduce the amount of soaking time to 20 or 30 minutes. This is not preferable, but you should still be able to coat and cook the clams.

procedure.summary: Mix the two flours and onion powder.
procedure.description: Stir together the all-purpose flour, corn flour, and onion powder in a shallow dish until thoroughly blended. Do this near the end of the soaking time, immediately before you prepare to take the clams out of the refrigerator.

procedure.summary: Dredge the clams in the coating.
Heat oil in a deep saucepan.
procedure.description: Fill a heavy saucepan with deep sides a little less than halfway with oil. Bring the oil up to roughly 365 degrees Fahrenheit (185 degrees Celsius) by heating it over medium-high heat on the stove. Use a candy thermometer to monitor the temperature. A deep fryer can also be used instead of a heavy saucepan.

Toss a few clams into the hot oil until they turn golden-brown. This should take roughly 3 minutes. Only fry a few clams at a time. Adding too many will lower the temperature of the oil too dramatically.

Remove fried clams from the hot oil using a heat-resistant slotted spoon. Drain the clams on several layers of clean paper towels and serve as desired. You can serve the clams with salt and pepper, lemon wedges, or tartar sauce. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/0\/0d\/Cook-Clams-Step-13Bullet1.jpg\/v4-459px-Cook-Clams-Step-13Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/0\/0d\/Cook-Clams-Step-13Bullet1.jpg\/v4-759px-Cook-Clams-Step-13Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"
